photo.description: La basilica di San Gaudenzio fu costruita nel punto più elevato di Novara tra il 1577 ed il 1690. L'incarico per il progetto fu afficato a Pellegrino Pellegrini, detto il Tibaldi, già architetto del cardinale Carlo Borromeo e di Filippo II di Spagna per il quale disegnò l'Escurial di Madrid. Nel maggio 1577 venne posata la prima pietra ma solo nel 1659 vennero completate le strutture architettoniche esterne. Ma il fattore architettonico più significativo è la grandiosa cupola, alta 121 metri, progettata dall'architetto-ingegnere Alessandro Antonelli (lo stesso della Mole di Torino), diventata simbolo grafico di Novara e visibile da tutti i lati della città. Il primo progetto della cupola di San Gaudenzio fu redatto da Alessandro Antonelli nel 1841. La struttura esteriore corrispondeva alle più moderne cupole di quel tempo, Saint Paul di Londra e Santa Genoveffa di Parigi. Negli anni seguenti l'edificazione rimase incompiuta a causa delle guerre per l'unità e l'indipendenza d'Italia e per sopraggiunti problemi di finanziamento. La costruzione fu poi completata definitivamente il 16 maggio 1878 con l’inserimento della statua del Salvatore, opera dello scultore milanese Pietro Zucchi. Novara - The dome of St. Gaudenzio The Basilica of San Gaudenzio was built on the highest point of Novara between 1577 and 1690. In the contract for the project was committed to Pellegrino Pellegrini, knon as Tibaldi, former architect of cardinal Carlo Borromeo and Philip II king of Spain for which designed the Escurial of Madrid. In May 1577 the foundation stone was laid but only in 1659 the outside architectural structures were totally completed. The most significant architectural factor is the great dome, 121 meters high, designed by the architect-engineer Alessandro Antonelli (the same as the Mole in Turin) that became the graphic symbol of Novara and it is visible from all sides of the city. The first draft of the dome of St. Gaudenzio was written by Alessandro Antonelli in 1841. The outer structure corresponded to the most modern domes that time, as St. Paul's in London and St. Genevieve of Paris. In the following years the building remained unfinished because of the wars for the unity and independence of Italy and due to unexpected financial problems. The building was finally completed in May 16, 1878 with the inclusion of the statue of Christ made by the sculptor Pietro Zucchi of Milan.
photo.tags: novara piemonte italia chiesa cupola campanile barocco cattedrale cielo tetti baroque belltower cathedral church dome roofs sky antonelli architettura architecture me2youphotographylevel1 me2youphotographylevel2 rememberthatmomentlevel1
photo.title: Novara – La cupola di San Gaudenzio

photo.description: The OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni (Big Repair Shops) are one of the last vestiges of Turin's industrial past. Built between 1885 and 1895, they became the first engine of development of the San Paolo neighborhood. Stretching over an area of more than 190,000 square meters, the buildings were used to build and repair locomotives and carriages. The H-shaped complex is a work of great architectural and monumental impact. Inside two rows of cast iron pillars create a spectacular nave and aisle structure, a true "industry cathedral". Abandoned for many years, the OGR are now the object of an architectural and functional restoration which aims to transform the complex into a large exhibit centre.
photo.tags: torino turin architetturaindustriale industrialarchitecture treni trains archeologiaindustriale industrialarchaeology ogr officinegrandiriparazioni
photo.title: OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni

photo.description: Dopplr sez: 2008 Personal annual report for David Orban San Diego Mar 02 to Mar 09 Turin July 01 Saint Petersburg Jul 02 to Jul 06 Sapporo Jul 27 to Aug 01 Tokyo Aug 02 to Aug 04 Los Angeles Sep 02 to Sep 07 Amsterdam Sep 24 to Sep 26 London Oct 06 to Oct 07 Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec In 2008, you mostly coincided with: Lawrence in San Diego and Sapporo Roo in Los Angeles, Amsterdam and London Francesco in Rome, Los Angeles and London marc in San Diego Zé in Amsterdam and Lisbon You took 14 trips in 2008, which added up to 73,612 km or 20% of the distance to the moon. In 2008, you spent 322 44 You have 125 travellers in your network. They travelled a total of 5,714,475 km in 2008, and everyone on Dopplr travelled a total of 1331.4 million km or 8.9 AU in 2008: the approximate distance to Saturn from the Earth as of January 2009. Your personal velocity for 2008 was 8.40 km/h, which is about the same as a butterfly. The 5 most popular cities in your network are Milan, Rome, London, New York and San Francisco. The furthest distance you travelled was to San Diego (9,796 km from Bergamo), which is the 25th most popular city on Dopplr. The shortest distance you travelled was to Crema (38 km from Bergamo). You spent the longest in San Diego, Anthony DiBitonto has a tip: The Rancho Bernardo Inn Outside the city but relaxing and warm atmosphere. See more on the city page for San Diego on Dopplr. Your carbon for 2008 8,692 kg CO2 Based on figures from Fueleconomy.gov, 1 x Hummer H3 4WD truck produces nearly 10 metric tonnes of CO2 a year. The visualisation above uses this figure to illustrate your carbon from Dopplr as calculated by our friends at amee.cc and is an approximation only. The city images above sourced from Flickr and are used under a Creative Commons Attribution Licence: The Sky Tonight by peasap, Superga - Cupola - Torino - Dino Olivieri by dino_olivieri, I turn my camera on - Saint Isaac's Cathedral by FLOODkOFF, Sapporo TV tower by daita, The Scenery of Cybercity by OiMax, Train Ride to the Beach? by Atwater Village Newbie, BicycleroofAmsterdam by Dan Kamminga and Spiders in the city by fabbio.
photo.tags: dopplr annual report 2008
photo.title: Davidorban Dopplr 2008

photo.description: National Register of Historic Places No. NRHP-76001666. Philadelphia City Hall, 1871 - 1901 1 Penn Square, Philadelphia, PA John McArthur, Jr. & Thomas U. Walter Philadelphia City Hall is the house of government for the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. At 167 m (548 ft), including the statue, it is the world's second-tallest masonry building, only .5 m (1 ft 8 in) shorter than Mole Antonelliana in Turin.[3][4] The weight of the building is borne by granite and brick walls up to 22 feet (6.7 m) thick, rather than steel; the principal exterior materials are limestone, granite, and marble. It was the tallest habitable building in the world from 1901 to 1908 and the tallest in Pennsylvania until 1932 when surpassed by the Gulf Tower in Pittsburgh. It remained the tallest building in Philadelphia until the construction of One Liberty Place (1984–1987) ended the informal gentlemen's agreement that limited the height of tall buildings in the city; it is currently the 16th-tallest building in Pennsylvania. The building was designed by Scottish-born architect John McArthur, Jr., in the Second Empire style, and was constructed from 1871 until 1901 at a cost of $24 million. Designed originally to be the world's tallest building, by the time it was completed it had already been surpassed by the Washington Monument and the Eiffel Tower, though it was indeed the world's tallest habitable building at the time of opening. It also was the first modern building (excluding the Eiffel Tower, see above) to be the world's tallest and also was the first secular habitable building to have this record: all previous world's tallest buildings were religious structures, whether European cathedrals or, for the previous 3,800 years, the Great Pyramid of Giza. Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall
photo.tags: kansassebastian philadelphia pennsylvania cityofbrotherlylove philadelphiacityhall nrhp76001666 pennsquare broadst johnmcarthurjr thomasuwalter secondempire
photo.title: 08b Philadelphia City Hall - NRHP-76001666 (E)

It was the tallest habitable building in the world from 1901 to 1908 and the tallest in Pennsylvania until 1932 when surpassed by the Gulf Tower in Pittsburgh. It remained the tallest building in Philadelphia until the construction of One Liberty Place (1984–1987) ended the informal gentlemen's agreement that limited the height of tall buildings in the city; it is currently the 16th-tallest building in Pennsylvania. The building was designed by Scottish-born architect John McArthur, Jr., in the Second Empire style, and was constructed from 1871 until 1901 at a cost of $24 million. Designed originally to be the world's tallest building, by the time it was completed it had already been surpassed by the Washington Monument and the Eiffel Tower, though it was indeed the world's tallest habitable building at the time of opening. It also was the first modern building (excluding the Eiffel Tower, see above) to be the world's tallest and also was the first secular habitable building to have this record: all previous world's tallest buildings were religious structures, whether European cathedrals or, for the previous 3,800 years, the Great Pyramid of Giza. Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall

photo.description: The inside of the cathedral is a soft creamy colour which wonderfully complements the black marble of the centre chapel. The side columns are made of simple cream marble which is in contrast to the alcove chapels which are very detailed and painted with rich colours and gold leaf.
photo.tags: italy turin cathedral stjohnthebaptist church
photo.title: Cathedral Ceiling

photo.description: Turin Cathedral (Italian: Duomo di Torino) is the major church of Turin, northern Italy. Dedicated to Saint John the Baptist (Italian San Giovanni Battista), it was built during 1491-1498 and it is adjacent to an earlier campanile (1470). The Chapel of the Holy Shroud, the current resting place of the Shroud of Turin, was added to the structure in 1668-1694.
photo.tags: 2470mm28g ancient d700 europe italian italy nikon catholic saintjohn shroud turin cathedral jesus burialcloth
photo.title: Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist in Turin, Italy

photo.description: The main chapel at the back of the Cathedral faces the entrance. The chapel is quietly decorated with black marble and painted with shades of grey with gold accents. The pulpit is richly carved. The space is divided into three parts by two rows of colums. The sides of the Cathedral house many small chapels devoted to various saints. The centre chapel is flanked by giant black doors on each side.
photo.tags: italy turin cathedral stjohnthebaptist church
photo.title: Cathedral Inside

photo.tags: turin torino italy zoer cathedral church steps
photo.title: Torino (Turin), Italy

photo.description: But really I don't know how to do the B&W in a proper way. In this case and since the photo is a reproduction of a masterpiece I am a little more humble than I use to be when cropping and converting to B&W... Anyway this is the Last Supper. Not the real one - but according to my books this is one of the best copies ever made. The painting (in color) can be seen in the Turin Cathedral. The real painting of Leonardo da Vinci has to be seen in MIlano at the church of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Remember to book in good time. I didn't do that, therefore I had to go for Torino...
photo.tags: duomoditorino lordssupper mysticalsupper leonardodavinci 1498 santamariadellegraziechurch cathedralofstjohnthebaptist densidstenadver turin torino italy lultimacena
photo.title: I like the painting and I like B&W

photo.description: September 26, 2008 (Sunday) - We took the train to Turino for the day and found the church containing the "Shroud of Turin". This box contains the supposed burial cloth of Jesus. We spent three weeks touring Italy. Since the fall of 2003, the daily focus of my eJournal and images blog has been on text. Later in July 2005, because of Flickr, I've been able create something which emphasizes a daily image or video clip. I'll shoot and add one each day. Doing so will remind me to constantly carry a camera and it'll be a more direct record of current, personal experiences.
photo.tags: turin turino italy shroudofturin box church religious cathedralofstjohnthebaptist dailypictureparade

photo.description: A large copy of Leonardo Da Vinci's Last Supper can also be found in the Cathedral.

photo.description: The OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni (Big Repair Shops) are one of the last vestiges of Turin's industrial past. Built between 1885 and 1895, they became the first engine of development of the San Paolo neighborhood. Stretching over an area of more than 190,000 square meters, the buildings were used to build and repair locomotives and carriages. The H-shaped complex is a work of great architectural and monumental impact. Inside two rows of cast iron pillars create a spectacular nave and aisle structure, a true "industry cathedral". Abandoned for many years, the OGR are now the object of an architectural and functional restoration which aims to transform the complex into a large exhibit centre.
photo.tags: torino turin architetturaindustriale industrialarchitecture treni trains archeologiaindustriale industrialarchaeology ogr officinegrandiriparazioni
photo.title: OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni

The H-shaped complex is a work of great architectural and monumental impact. Inside two rows of cast iron pillars create a spectacular nave and aisle structure, a true "industry cathedral". Abandoned for many years, the OGR are now the object of an architectural and functional restoration which aims to transform the complex into a large exhibit centre.
photo.tags: torino turin architetturaindustriale industrialarchitecture treni trains archeologiaindustriale industrialarchaeology ogr officinegrandiriparazioni
photo.title: OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni

photo.description: The OGR - Officine Grandi Riparazioni (Big Repair Shops) are one of the last vestiges of Turin's industrial past. Built between 1885 and 1895, they became the first engine of development of the San Paolo neighborhood. Stretching over an area of more than 190,000 square meters, the buildings were used to build and repair locomotives and carriages. The H-shaped complex is a work of great architectural and monumental impact. Inside two rows of cast iron pillars create a spectacular nave and aisle structure, a true "industry cathedral". Abandoned for many years, the OGR are now the object of an architectural and functional restoration which aims to transform the complex into a large exhibit centre.

photo.tags: torino hdr mole italy
photo.title: Torino dalla Mole

photo.description: Is it a a vestige of a pagan temple, a secret location for a Christian chivalric order or is it just a misunderstood but impressive Neoclassical temple. Sure it has the signs that make it a must visit for every Da Vinci Code worshipper, but that alone should not be the only reason to come to this beautiful church. Apart from those famed items, there are also murals by Eugene Delacroix decorating one of the chapels, a statue of Joan of Arc, a display of the Shroud of Turin and some modern stained glass work. Perhaps, what is it is more renowned for is its Organ, whose music I was lucky enough to catch while resting in the cavernous interiors of the church around noon. On Sundays after the mass, one can get a chance to actually go see the artist play the organ sometime around noon. Even though it is off the beaten path, it certainly got some popularity by the famed bestseller - and the added crowds is something that this church can use while undergoing renovation on its half-finished towers St Sulpice Paris France
photo.tags: stsulpice france paris stsulpicecathedral sonydslra100 sigma70700f456 prioryofsion roseline davincicode danbrown
photo.title: Priory of Sion

photo.description: National Register of Historic Places No. NRHP-76001666. Philadelphia City Hall, 1871 - 1901 1 Penn Square, Philadelphia, PA John McArthur, Jr. & Thomas U. Walter Philadelphia City Hall is the house of government for the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. At 167 m (548 ft), including the statue, it is the world's second-tallest masonry building, only .5 m (1 ft 8 in) shorter than Mole Antonelliana in Turin.[3][4] The weight of the building is borne by granite and brick walls up to 22 feet (6.7 m) thick, rather than steel; the principal exterior materials are limestone, granite, and marble. It was the tallest habitable building in the world from 1901 to 1908 and the tallest in Pennsylvania until 1932 when surpassed by the Gulf Tower in Pittsburgh. It remained the tallest building in Philadelphia until the construction of One Liberty Place (1984–1987) ended the informal gentlemen's agreement that limited the height of tall buildings in the city; it is currently the 16th-tallest building in Pennsylvania. The building was designed by Scottish-born architect John McArthur, Jr., in the Second Empire style, and was constructed from 1871 until 1901 at a cost of $24 million. Designed originally to be the world's tallest building, by the time it was completed it had already been surpassed by the Washington Monument and the Eiffel Tower, though it was indeed the world's tallest habitable building at the time of opening. It also was the first modern building (excluding the Eiffel Tower, see above) to be the world's tallest and also was the first secular habitable building to have this record: all previous world's tallest buildings were religious structures, whether European cathedrals or, for the previous 3,800 years, the Great Pyramid of Giza. Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall
photo.tags: kansassebastian philadelphia pennsylvania cityofbrotherlylove philadelphiacityhall nrhp76001666 pennsquare broadst johnmcarthurjr thomasuwalter secondempire
photo.title: 08c Philadelphia City Hall - NRHP-76001666 (E)

It remained the tallest building in Philadelphia until the construction of One Liberty Place (1984–1987) ended the informal gentlemen's agreement that limited the height of tall buildings in the city; it is currently the 16th-tallest building in Pennsylvania. The building was designed by Scottish-born architect John McArthur, Jr., in the Second Empire style, and was constructed from 1871 until 1901 at a cost of $24 million. Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_City_Hall
